Above all, and most pathetic, he left no one in doubt of Segun's paternity. Segun was not his son but was adopted only out of compassion. He finally declared his dancing naked in the public as a selfless step in the best interest of the lady's family; to guide them in making informed decision. Without waiting for response or reaction, he walked out on the gathering. Others of the groom's side, seated facing the other family like the opposition in a British parliament and looking beaten by a simple majority vote, wished it were all but a bad dream. The atmosphere was imbued with uneasy silence. A dropped pin at the moment would sound like a pot tipped over; hanging in the air was tension of pandemic magnitude. They finally plucked up the courage and stood all up at once managing to drag themselves away from the scene without uttering a word to bid their to-be, or not-to-be, in-laws farewell. Segun would not move an inch from his seat. He felt his whole world tumbling down.

In recent times, the number and variety of zoonotic pathogens has grown exponentially. These pathogens are transmitted from animals or animal products to humans by either direct, indirect contact or through contaminated food (1). It is estimated that 60% of all human infections are zoonotic (2). The World Health Organization (WHO) has identified six major diseases as emerging threats to global security: SARS; Avian influenza A; Ebola hemorrhagic fever; Lassa fever; Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fevers and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus.
According to the CDC, there are 32 zebrafish disease models for infectious disease research (3), with many more in development. Zebrafish are a model organism because they share about 70% genetic similarity with mammals and humans (4).
Zebrafish are also a good choice for research due their short life span (3–5 years) and relatively low cost for maintaining large colonies. They also produce about 80 live offspring every time they spawn, allowing researchers access to a large enough population to do statistical analysis on results.

The five-and-a-half-feet tall man of God stood on the podium and for the next two to three minutes would say nothing; his eyes roamed wild among the puzzled people. The gaze went to the choir and stayed for some troubling seconds. They were well dressed  every one female among them had something in the name of a hat to cover her head, as opposed to some members on the floor who adopted a free stance. Their music, too, had been superb right from the praises to the just concluded rendition. So, what is it? The stare left them wondering as it went 180 degrees to the Pastor's aides standing at ease on his left. Neither of them had come late for the pre-service ministers' prayer and every ministerial assignment given to them so far in the service they had carried out to the best of their abilities. Why the suspicious look? His eyes turned over to the degrees they had come to meet the bewildered gape of the floor members. What is wrong with Pastor? Hope all is well. We have been divided on caste lines since time immemorial but there are also some positive developments which show that we have been progressing towards social justice and equality.
The Indian constitution is an embodiment not just for democracy but for the social and economic progress as well.
In this regard, it has been successful in providing equal opportunities to women by enshrining the right to equality in its preamble itself and also by providing separate representation for Dalits in parliament through reserved seats under Article 330. Similarly, it has given reservation to other weaker sections through Article 15(4).
There are provisions like Articles 17-21 regarding untouchability which prohibits discrimination based on religion or caste; Articles 39(1) & (2) regarding equality before law; Articles 46

After the death of Evagoras his kingdom was divided up among three rulers until it was reunited by Idreus I around 340 BC. It was then ruled jointly under a system called koinobratia - meaning "partnership" which allowed each ruler to retain their own title.

There are three different ways of specifying namespaces in SQL syntax; they are [database].[schema].[table], {database} {schema} {table}, or [{provider};{dsn}] . prefix_text: As is the case with imagery, decades of effort have been spent in trying to generate and reproduce sound that is faithful to the original. The results of these efforts
reference_text: are sound recorders, high-fidelity systems, and systems for sensing sound. Think of the highest-quality hi-fi systems produced by the largest company in the music industry. Even in these devices, when sound is recorded some of it is lost; or when you turn on a hi-fi you always hear a hissing sound before the music starts. However, the sounds that are the products of the human body's technology are extremely sharp and clear. A human ear never perceives a sound accompanied by a hissing sound or with atmospherics as does a hi-fi; rather, it perceives sound exactly as it is, sharp and clear. This is the way it has been since the creation of man.

generated_text.0:
have not been very encouraging, and we still hear many recordings that are either too bright or too dull; too soft or too hard; or too close or too far away. The main reasons can be traced back to our lack of understanding about how a listener's auditory perception interacts with the recording process.
Sound is a mechanical wave of energy transmitted through air (or other medium) as alternating variations in pressure. We hear this sound as an oscillation of pressure at our eardrums, which is sensed by hair cells (in an organ called the cochlea) located along a spiral-shaped structure inside the ear canal.

The crisis had been building for some time in several countries but came to a head when France, on February 18-19, 1971, repudiated its obligations under both the IMF and BIS to hold dollar assets in gold. On March I5 President de Gaulle announced that French banks would no longer redeem dollars for gold. These actions forced an immediate reassessment by both American and Western European financial institutions of their ability to maintain confidence in the Bretton Woods system.

The crisis was triggered largely as result of two factors: (I) a substantial change from previous economic policy, whereby many governments adopted a more expansionary fiscal stance; and (2) increasing pressure by the United States on foreign central banks to keep domestic interest rates low. The combination of these two factors caused foreign central bank reserves held at home or at their foreign exchange banks abroad to become depleted rapidly as they were drawn down for use within domestic economies. This, together with other factors such as the large U.S. current account deficit which made it impossible for foreign banks holding dollar assets to convert them back into hard currency without causing massive losses on those reserves themselves, led eventually toward de Gaulle's decision.

The United States Government and the people of the United States have been profoundly impressed by this tragedy [the murder of a young American by Communist Chinese in Peking]. It was a shocking and barbaric crime and we are appalled at its commission against one of our own citizens.
The Secretary of State said that he hoped there would be no attempt to retaliate for this crime and that we should try instead to obtain through normal diplomatic channels information on the facts which led our citizen into such a situation. The Department of State has requested the Government concerned, through appropriate channels in Peking or in Washington if necessary, for all available information regarding circumstances leading up to this tragic occurrence as well as any information regarding possible future developments.
We have also directed that all information be gathered regarding the condition under which our citizen may remain alive in Peking. We wish him every possible assistance if he survives his ordeal and may remain alive until his release.

But London opposed any such aid lest it be used against them or encourage Egypt to take a hard line on the base negotiations. In January 1953, London persuaded Truman to wait a while longer. On May 7, Prime Minister Churchill asked President Eisenhower to continue to delay arms aid; again Washington agreed. In late November, just before the Anglo-American Bermuda meeting, Eden wrote: "In my view an allotment to Egypt at this juncture could not fail to give publicity to a major divergence of British and American policies, and thus to have a serious effect on Anglo-American relations. It would have the appearance of encouraging the Egyptians to stand out in their demands against us and it would remove an important inducement to them to reach an agreement with us." Apparently, the British again won their point.

prefix_text: Years later, when that second manuscript of George Boustronios's Chronicle resurfaced in a monastery at Mt Athos, an explanation of a sort did appear
reference_text: . Somerville by then was dead, but I'd kept an interest in the period of James the Bastard as a hobby because of Somerville's strange story. This second manuscript contained additions to Boustronios's Chronicle and life of James the Bastard, additions written by one Petros Kouklianos, a priest from near Paphos. In the few extra paragraphs he'd added, Kouklianos touched on some more of the scandals of that turbulent period at the very end of Lusignan rule. In one paragraph, he briefly referred to a nobleman's daughter, married off at fourteen (as was the custom) to a much older man for reasons of family advantage. There were few places a nobleman's daughter might go with her maid and her bodyguard, but the cathedral was one of them. And it was there that she met a young priest/confessor with whom, in Kouklianos's polite language, the girl had "formed an attachment". The story ended when their secret was betrayed for money by her bodyguard. One day, he left his post at the cathedral door and her husband's retainers stormed in to drag the priest up one of the octagonal staircases to the roof, taking him out onto the flying buttress from where they tossed him like a heavy sack onto the pavement below. They sent the girl to a nunnery where she gave birth to a boy six months later. They killed the child and threw it down a dried-up well. Kouklianos doesn't record what happened to the mother.

According to this account (now lost), the Chronicle was originally intended only for internal circulation and was therefore written in code; but it had nevertheless found its way into circulation outside the palace and had been read by a few people who were not partakers either of its code or of its secret meaning. The first part contained the usual information about dynasties and genealogies, while the second was concerned with events that happened after 1067. In other words, it dealt with contemporary history; but instead of using plain Greek words and phrases to describe these contemporary affairs - as anyone would have expected - he had made use only "of those expressions which are peculiarly appropriate" (to these affairs), thus "rendering his work unintelligible not only to common readers" but also "to all those unacquainted with secret learning". This last clause is important: Boustroniouos himself was not the author's true addressee; rather he represented only one stage in what might be called an "initiatory chain". The first time my doctor said those words, it was a relief: "It's very effective but not very addictive." She said that if I were addicted to anything it would be to cigarettes and to coffee -- two substances she didn't believe were harmful for me at this point in my life.

That was a decade ago now, and I still use coffee and cigarettes (and have tried marijuana but never got into using it on regular basis), though not as much anymore as back then when I was smoking a couple cigarettes an hour while drinking a pot of black tea or coffee in the morning.

The end, of course, came in the most banal of ways. I stopped outside the Tube Station on the way home to buy The Evening News. There was going to be some headline the Whips had been worried about. I hurried down to the Tube and it was only when I sat down on the train that I could see the newspaper-seller had made some mistake. Instead of The Evening News, he'd given me an old copy of the Daily Worker. It was crisp and white and had been lovingly ironed as though it was The Times delivered on a silver tray in an upper-class Victorian household. It was the very neatness of the folds and the pressing that were so terrifying. I could visualise the hands that would have picked it up and read it. This beautifully folded paper had a finality to it, like a judgement or a death sentence...

prefix_text: Things changed in my late-twenties. My marriage broke up and I shan't bore those of you who don't know them with the details.
reference_text: I was a bit wrecked and one of my friends said a new challenge would help me to get through it. So, I made the jump, left the Gallery and set up as a freelance restorer. The work wasn't well-paid or plentiful, but I did get a helpful six months as the assistant restorer on a project to restore the Fifteenth century wood panel paintings of Saints in a Church in East Anglia. The paintings had been painted over at the Reformation and the Saints had been lost under a new surface of severe Protestant texts, making the point, I suppose, that under Protestantism, the parishioners would be able to read and no longer needed pictures to help them get closer to God. I can't say I believed it myself. I don't think literacy levels had improved that much.

However, I found myself with a young daughter and, to be honest, I didn’t really have a clue how to look after her or raise her properly.
My parents were very helpful during this time and gave me some very good advice about my daughter's upbringing that has stood me in good stead ever since.
When I was young (and probably still am) I was never one to take advice on board unless it came from people who had more experience than myself. This was probably because of my overinflated opinion of myself (which still exists), but also because of the fear of losing my individuality. As a result, most advice went in one ear and out again – or I ignored it altogether!
It wasn’t until later on as an adult that I realised the wisdom behind much of that ‘common knowledge’. My own experiences have led many people – even those older than me – to seek my opinions and advice on certain things.
One thing that has always been true for all children is they are individuals in their own right; they need different things from their parents at different points in their lives.
I don't mean to say you should never give them your opinions and views about life, but you also need be prepared for your child having different views than yours on how

The magnification revealed that all three paintings used an identical technique for laying down colour. The ground, which appears light brown in places and pink in others (a colour that can be seen most clearly on the right-hand side of both portraits) is made up of white and red chalks laid down with a palette knife. Then, using red ochre oil paint mixed with gum-arable or egg-yolk as a medium (depending on the period when it was painted), a series of thin glazes were laid down in various layers. The glaze on this painting is so thin that it allows you just to make out where there's been any scratching or scraping underneath - as there has obviously been on both portraits. In fact it's not too difficult to make out where an attempt has obviously been made to correct the colour balance between one side - presumably done first - and the other.
There are several areas that have not been finished off properly, which suggests that work was interrupted or not completed.
There are other clues too: a number places where an attempt seems to have failed at creating highlights, particularly on some facial features and around some jewellery.

I am writing about my experiences with the United Nations in 1978 and 1979, when I was an intern in the Department for Social Affairs of UNCTAD. (The full name of this UN agency is: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.) I am still very interested today by what happens at UNCTAD and what it is trying accomplish.

It was an unusual time to work at a UN agency; we were in between two major international crises, one over the Suez Canal (between Britain-France-Isreal and Egypt) which had just ended; and one over the Iranian Revolution which would end only after two years or more.

The UN had been created after World War II by representatives of fifty governments at a conference held during a single month: April-June 1945 in San Francisco, California. At that time there were about one billion people on earth.

prefix_text: In short, the Master of Hamburg's Dance had only survived at all because of the brave actions of one man. In the Reformation when the Protestant iconocl
reference_text: lasts (if that's the right word) were vandalising the former Catholic churches, tearing the religious art from their walls and destroying it, the mob here had been frustrated by the priest of the church where I was working. To stop the mob from entering, he had locked himself inside the church and poured molten lead into the locks. Dried flowers and plants from the holy site would have been carried back home in the Gau by the pilgrim as a permanent link to the shrine.

In this excerpt from The Book Thief by Markus Zusak, how are the following literary devices used: allusion, metaphor?

Expert Answers
M.P. Ossa eNotes educator| Certified Educator

The quote in your question contains two literary devices: allusion and metaphor.

First of all, let us discuss the meaning of each device:

In an allusion we can find references to things that are outside of literature and are not explained or described in detail by their writer or author. Instead, these references imply or make use if a reader having prior knowledge about said things so as to make their meaning understood without further explanations.

Metaphor is the use of one image or idea in reference with another image/idea in order to make the comparison between them.

Now that we know what these two devices mean, let us see how they are applied within this quote:

  • The author uses an "allusion" when he makes reference about getting pregnant as a means of creating a "future" instead of the usual and more traditional means such marriage.
  • The comparison between pregnancy as creating future is done via the metaphor "devour".

history of the word 'quintessential'."
The word was coined in English by Thomas Nashe in 1589, but the Latin quintessentia had been around since at least the 14th century. It literally meant "fifth essence" - "essence" as a chemical term (meaning a thing's fundamental substance), and fifth because there are four elements (earth, air, fire and water) plus one extra. That fifth element was thought to be the source of life: the aether or heavenly fire.
Aether is also known for another reason: its use to refer metaphorically to space. This is not because it really was thought to be there (it wasn't - it was actually discovered by scientists who were trying NOTto prove that there wasn't), but because in classical philosophy space itself was conceived as being filled with this mysterious fifth element.

A few months ago I was in such a hovel. The mother had recently died, and a young widow was raising four children alone. She told me that she had always loved her husband; he would never come home drunk and beat his wife; he was always kind.
She did not tell me how much she missed him.
The youngest child was about three years old.  He told us that he wanted candy. We bought the candy, which we gave him. Then another child wanted candy also; then another. All five children wanted candy. We gave each one some.
After all were fed and quieted again, the mother told us a story about an older girl who used sometimes when the children were restless to say “Candy!” The girl would then open her mouth as if she were going to cry out “I want some” but would stop herself just before she could say it: “I am thankful that I do NOT want any,” she used to say.
I said this is what you should teach your four youngest: “I am thankful that I DO NOT WANT ANY.” And they did learn it; and it helped them.

  1. Create a Budget

Creating budgets for every aspect within an organization is one great way to measure financial stability over time.

  • Budgeting helps you know how much money should be spent on certain areas such as marketing campaigns.
  • It also helps with the decision making process when it comes down prioritizing which investments are worth pursuing at any given time.

The recovery from the Great Recession remains a long one in parts like Detroit or Atlanta where unemployment rates remain well over 8 percent. Sometimes in winter, if the schoolchildren got lucky, the cold mountain air might creep down the valley to commingle with the wet coastal action and produce snow. knowledge meant I would be a better long term employee and they could earn more money. This made it a win-win.

In business, there's no such thing as 'sharing' your knowledge.

There is sharing for the sake or gaining a greater market position and then there is sharing for the purposes of helping your employees grow and become better at what you do so they will stay with you longer. This latter method does not work if you have not already built a relationship that's based on trust.

The more valuable your employees are to you, the more valuable their information should be in your company - not less. If they leave you to join someone else who can use their information more effectively and profitably than yourself then that person wins, not yours.

The best way to keep your best people with you is by creating an environment where everyone thrives and can develop their skills. If they know they will be given responsibility as quickly as possible then that creates a culture of ownership.

If your employees feel valued and respected by you then this will be reflected in the value they give back in work performance, loyalty and retention rates.

The statement given describes a psychological phenomenon known as "emotional avoidance." When individuals consciously or unconsciously try hard to push away or forget painful experiences or emotions from their past, their subconscious mind often reacts by intensifying these feelings. This makes them seem more vivid and overwhelming when they do surface. Therefore, instead of helping us get rid of negative feelings, this effort can actually make them stronger when they manifest in our present lives.

To understand why this happens requires delving into how our minds process information and emotions. Our brains have an innate drive towards equilibrium - known technically within psychology circles as homeostasis - which essentially means we seek comfort and avoid discomfort equally strongly.

The Saa'n is a faction in the 15th century AD that has come from another world. They arrived with their ships in 478AD on Earth, landing on land that was once part or the Kingdoms but had become a wasteland due an event which caused it to be uninhabitable.

They are peaceful people who have no wish for conquest and only wish to find their way back home but they have been unable too as their technology cannot be used on Earth as it is not compatible.


In ancient times, the ancestors were known as Saa'ns. They were a group who lived as nomads across a desert continent called Sahn'ta'n'kai (The Land Of Many Colors) with their flocks.

At one point during history they had been ruled over by a group called The Council of Five who ruled from The Tower Of Five Kings. This was destroyed by The Warlock King (who was also known at The Dark Lord) in order that he could take full control over Sahn'ta'n'kai and his followers.

The Saan is an organization dedicated towards preserving and protecting creatures that society deems unnatural. It has been around for over two hundred years, with its members mostly being humans who are passionate towards protecting these species from extinction. The organization has several facilities across North America and Europe.

Saan's primary goal is to protect and preserve the world’s most dangerous and misunderstood creatures by providing resources, funding, and safe habitats for them. It also aims to educate people worldwide about these magnificent animals so that they may gain more respect and empathy toward them.

In order for an individual or group interested in joining Saan must first pass a rigorous background check before being accepted into their ranks; only those who show a sincere passion for conservation efforts will be considered worthy enough.

I was impressed by their dedication to protecting these creatures that society often disregards as harmful threats instead of beautiful beings deserving just as much love & admiration as any other living thing on earth! When I first started working with this poem I wasn’t sure where it would lead me. The first line is the most important one, I felt: “There are some parts of me that I don’t show”. I decided not to focus on what is hidden or covered up but rather on the feeling behind it, which is insecurity or lack of self confidence. That’s how the poem turned out to be.
What’s your favourite line and why?
I like all of them equally because they describe different situations and feelings about being covered up by others’ opinions (Cyclopic) vs feeling exposed (human).
This poem reminds me about how we hide our emotions and feelings when we feel insecure or vulnerable in front others. It also shows how difficult it can be for someone with such a strong personality as Cyclops to change her attitude towards herself and accept herself for who she really is.

What is homocysteinemia?
Homocysteine is an amino acid in your blood and is made from another amino acid called methionine. Homocysteine is a normal product of metabolism and your body will normally convert it back into useful proteins. If too much homcysteine builds up in the blood, however, you have elevated homocysteinemia or hyperhomocysteinemia.
What causes elevated homcysteine levels?
Elevated homcysteinemia can be caused by either genetic problems with certain enzymes or by deficiencies of folate (also called folic acid) or vitamin B12.
How common is elevated homcyteinmia?
Elevated homcyteinmia occurs in about 10 percent of people without other conditions and about 80 percent of people with other medical conditions.

Astronauts are protected from harmful radiation by thick metal walls of Earth's protective magnetosphere and its 250-mile-high ozone layer that screens harmful rays.
When astronauts venture outside their spacecraft on space walks called extra-vehicular activity (EVA), they wear protective suits to keep them alive in a hostile environment that is extremely hot during daytime on the side facing the sun and extremely cold at night when it is on the side facing away from the sun.
Astronauts on space walks must carry with themselves all life-sustaining systems that are built into an airliner for its passenger comfort.
Space suits for E.V.A.'s have life support systems that provide 150 pounds worth of air pressure. There also are air conditioners to prevent them from overheating, and oxygen masks to protect them should something go wrong with their helmet oxygen delivery system.
They have gloves for working with their hands on objects in space as well as to allow them some control over their body temperature by flexing muscles in their fingers or palms.

The United Federation Space Navy was a branch of service within Starfleet dedicated to the protection and expansion into space of the United Federation of Planets, as well as other allied nations' territory. As such it was charged with protecting all planets, colonies or outposts belonging either to those powers or those who had agreed upon protection from the Federation in the past.
The USS Voyager was a member ship that served within this department and fought alongside her sister ships against their enemies in space during both conflicts against The Borg Collective and The Dominion.
Starfleet has been around for over 200 years but the USS Voyager did not come along until about 20 years after Starfleet itself came into existence; it wasn't until 2371 when the ship was launched from San Francisco's Starbase Four that Star Trek: Voyager was created. The museum's layout is a bit confusing at first glance. It is divided into three sections: one with exhibits about life before and during slavery; one devoted to life for freed slaves in post-Emancipation Texas, including the history of Reconstruction; and one devoted to African American life in Texas in our time, and its struggles against racial prejudice.
The last part of this section, which is also called "Texas' Long Journey," covers more recent events like segregation and Jim Crow laws. The displays are divided by decade from 1950 on up through today, with exhibits on each decade focusing primarily but not exclusively on events in Texas.
There are also a few artifacts that are very important but do not fit neatly into any one section of history: for example there's an old slave cabin (dating back over 150 years), which has been preserved as it was when it left slavery; or "the lynching tree"—which hangs outside one room in what used be called "the slave quarters."

We have a few options for entertainment in winter such as going out for food and drinks with friends or family members in our favorite restaurant or bar. If you are not interested at all in going out you can stay home with your friends and watch a movie together.

And this trend is also affecting me personally because my father moved back to his childhood town when he retired last year (he now lives about 80 km from me) so that he could be closer to his grandchildren who all live here.

I was cruising around the main streets, when out popped a group with a man holding his arm out to stop me. I stopped and they told us there had been some shooting nearby, so we drove around that area for about ten minutes or so before going back into City Central.
I stopped at another checkpoint and was waved through, but then had no clue what to do next. It felt like we had gone in circles for about 30 minutes or more before I decided it would be better if someone else did some investigating while we headed back home.
I was driving in my car, listening intently over police radio when suddenly there were sirens coming from every direction! It looked as though something major went down just as quickly after our last stop on patrol, but thankfully no one got hurt!

The Neurolink is a form of brain computer interface technology developed for use by the US military in the 2010s, which allows a human's mind directly communicate with machines, such as the Holographic Matrix and other advanced weaponry.[5][1]

In use during World War III, Neurolinks were used primarily for the control of Holographic Matrix drones and as part an interrogation process to obtain data on the enemy forces.[3] During his service in Afghanistan Dr. Krycek was fitted with a Neurolink implant by the US military after he was captured by them as part their interrogation process.[4]

Krycek later used this implant during his time working with S.H.I.E.L.D., to access the HoloMatrix and retrieve data on his target.[6] It was subsequently removed from Krycke's mind when Agent Maria Hill discovered he had become infected through his link.

In 2015, KGB agent Alexander Gromov was implanted one in order for him and fellow agents working under him at Red Room to control S.H.I.E.L.D.'s Matrix drone

It's not easy for a writer or editor at The Atlantic Monthly (or anywhere else) to say no. There are few more important skills than getting people who want something to say yes. But sometimes it's necessary to decline.
The latest instance is an e-mail from someone who wants us in his company's database. He has no problem with the fact that we're going online; it's just that he doesn't want us there.
It's a common enough sentiment, and one that deserves respect: I don't want strangers looking me up in the phone book either.
It is not, however, an argument against the Web itself — or even against the idea of online databases.
The reason is this: The Web has been a tremendous success because its databases are open — open to all of our eyes and fingers. If we had kept those data sets locked away in private warehouses like so many corporate secrets instead we'd have nothing but a buncha databases nobody can see. That would be a tragedy indeed.
There are some reasons why you might think otherwise, though — reasons that have little if anything whatsoever do with privacy concerns and lots to do with the nature of the Internet itself as it exists today

prefix_text: The "point" was at the mouth of the inlet. It was a narrow strip of water that connected the inlet area to the ocean. Large rocks
reference_text: called the "jetties" marked the gateway, and waves of sand dunes lapped out in all directions on both the inlet and ocean sides of the "point." The area was a nesting place for many of the wildlife species of the area because it was virtually cut off from the vacationers. The inlet side of the "point" could only be reached by boat, and could only be reached by those familiar enough with the channels to maneuver through the labyrinth of sand bars. There wasn't a public beach access at this end of the peninsula, so I pulled off of the road between two rental properties that were clearly deserted for the winter. I wrapped my book up in my towel and slipped unnoticed between the two houses. A narrow planked walkway led to the shoreline. The beach was much wider at this end, but it was cut off by a large seawall that separated the beach area from the jetties. I tucked my towel wrapped book into my zipped up jacked and hoisted myself to the top of the seawall, careful not to cut myself on the barnacles that covered the weathered posts.

and sandbars were found at both sides of this passage and it was often blocked by shifting sands, so that the opening would close, cutting off communication between these two regions. It would also become very dangerous for ships to cross when an opening did exist due to strong currents.
There are several points of interest around here.
The point where we are standing now is actually two points joined together by a sand bar that formed as sand and soil washed downstream from land erosion were carried into this area over time until they finally met up again on both ends creating an almost solid wall between them. This is what's known as an island point; there may only be one small opening in it that allows water and animals through but it acts like an actual barrier for most things trying to pass through.
The point where we are standing right now is also known as the Old Point Loma Lighthouse because it used to mark the way up into San Diego Bay before they made one further north called Point Loma. There's not much left there today except for old ruins and some graffiti but you can still see some remains if you look closely enough!

prefix_text: The view from the top of the seawall was stunning. The beach fanned out in all directions with small tidal pools dipping in and out of the landscape.
reference_text: The gulls and sand lappers seemed not to notice my intrusion, as they darted in and out of the sea foam along the water's edge. There was a narrow lagoon that dipped towards a large gated home nestled just off of the jetties. The architecture of the house was quite different from the other surrounding homes. Unlike the other homes along the peninsula, this house wasn't lifted by pilings, but it rested along the dunes. The main house was a gray two story, with the center of the upper story encompassed by a large circular glass lookout, much like one would see atop a lighthouse. Inside the crow's nest, a large lamplight could be seen from the shore, but in my many summers here, I had never seen it lit. There were also three smaller bungalows that were connected to the main house by stone walkways. Bare pergolas encompassed each walkway. These cottages blended so easily into the landscape that one would barely notice them at all.

The Sironians (also known as Serians or Sironi) were an humanoid species native to the planet Sironia in the Saron system. A member of that species was known as a "Siron".


Saron system

The Saron System


During their history, this alien race had developed advanced technologies which allowed them build a vast underground city beneath Mount Tabor on their homeworld.

At some point after that time, however, their civilization began to collapse and they retreated into isolationism in a state they called "the ageless night".

The collapse led them to abandon many technologies which were deemed too dangerous by their leaders; among these were the weapons which could have destroyed entire cities.

By 2267 AD, only one-third remained of this ancient race's once-great population.[1]

By 43930 BC,[2] they would become extinct.

For thousands of years people have turned to nature for help when they are sick and in need. One way is through seawater therapy or "marinotherapy". Marinotherapy is a type alternative medicine that uses seawater as the healing source.
The salt water contains trace elements and minerals which are essential to the human body's health and well being as well as a variety of other beneficial substances. Saltwater also has natural disinfectant properties.
The most widely-known form marinitherapy is seaweed bath therapy. Seaweed bath therapy has been used by indigenous cultures and is used in many countries today including France (France produces 80%of all marine pharmaceutical products worldwide), Mexico (where they have more than 20 different types of seaweed baths), Germany, Japan, Korea and many parts Africa.
In addition to seaweed baths there are salt-water showers or steam rooms which use high concentrations sea salts to create an intense heat therapy. There may be other methods that I am unaware but these are some basic types.

The given statement is an example of a metaphor.

A simile compares two things using "like" or "as," while a metaphor directly states that one thing is another without using these words. Here’s how you can distinguish between them:

- **Simile**: "Samantha runs like the wind."
- **Metaphor**: "Samantha is the wind."

prefix_text: I sat on the dunes as if in a trance, watching the waves roll onto the shoreline. Were those churning waters actually my home? Did I
reference_text: belong among the breakers covered in sea foam and bathed with sunlight, or did I belong nowhere at all. I could not deny that I had lived an entire seventeen years feeling consistently out of sync with the world, and now that I knew what I was, I only felt more out of place. I watched wave after wave until they all seemed to run together. Their crests seemed to be reaching out to me, and their faces seemed to be calling my name. I stood and moved closer and closer to the water's edge, and the closer I got, the more it seemed to call to me. Its call became a pull, as if its hands were on my shoulders pulling me closer and closer. My eyes closed and with each step I was drawn nearer and nearer to the choppy breakers. It sang to me. It called my name. I stepped into the surf and let myself go.

The waves rolled closer still...
A cold dread gripped hold of me and all around me I heard whispers on wind. They called out to be answered but no words would come forth from lips dry cracked by thirst or lungs parched with heat. And then suddenly there it came: laughter echoing off cliffs so steep they seemed almost vertical against blue sky above them; voices raised in jubilation mingling together into one grand chorus of sound - all around us now...
It wasn’t until morning arrived before things began to settle back down again – though somehow still felt different somehow changed forevermore...
And now I knew what truly made up our world...not just sandstone cliffs or saltwater oceans but each other too!

This was a new world for us, but it had always been our way of life in my culture and in other places. This way of being was the only way of life for those who were able. The people who were disabled or otherwise unable did not have access this power. They had to do what everyone else did: survive by the skin on their backs.
But there were others who could do what we could: those with a disability or other physical difference. There must’ve been thousands, even hundreds of thousands of them all across our world.
But there weren’t enough able people like me to help them all out. We were spread too thin.
There wasn’t time, and it wouldn’t be safe anyway, but I wanted so much more than that for these people.
I didn’t need to go on living like this any longer. I knew exactly how I’d feel after this life: like someone else’s burden; someone else’s liability; like an inconvenience and a nuisance; not worth saving because they couldn't save themselves.

Sirens were beautiful women who lived near the sea. In Greek mythology they were dangerous because their sweet songs lured sailors into treacherous shallow seas where their ships could be smashed against reefs by the wind gods.
In ancient Greece, Sirens would appear in stories where sailors would be warned not only to beware of these dangerous women, but also to take heed of the Siren call of the gods.
Siringen is an archaic Dutch word for the Saxon goddess Eostre who was celebrated at spring festivals in England and Germany during pre-Christian times with offerings of eggs and rabbits (her sacred animals). It also referred to a spring goddess.
The word “Easter” itself comes from this Germanic goddess who was associated both with fertility symbols such as rabbits or birds that lay eggs for new life each year; but also represented rebirth in springtime when nature came back alive again after winter had ended its reign of cold weather on our planet Earth.

There was no visible trail to the embankment, but I could barely make out a steep footpath through an array of overgrown vegetation. prefix_text: "Well, William's mother desperately wanted a normal life for him. She and her husband were very successful in their business and were able to blend in effortlessly among
reference_text: the humans. They enrolled William into a normal first grade class where he was well liked among the children but was careful to keep a safe distance. There was a young girl in his class by the name of Emily. She followed him everywhere. She sat next to him and continued to peruse a friendship with him despite the fact that he continuously pushed her away. Over time William started to care about the girl as well, and they became good friends. William knew to be very careful around the human children, but on Valentine's Day sweet Emily brought William a Valentine's Day card. When he turned around on the playground, she planted a big kiss upon William's lips. All that he had tried to guard her from, all that he had feared came to light that day, as young Emily's life energy was transferred to William. Poor Emily's lifeless body fell to the ground, as William stared on in horror as his only friend died. Of course no one could find William at fault, and the girl's death was ruled an undiagnosed fatal medical condition, but poor young William knew the truth, and was forced to live with the guilt that comes with taking a life. It was at that time that his parents found me, and relocated from Charleston to the area. He was immediately pulled from school and hidden away here by his parents out of fear that if Sironian officials found out about the incident, then they would all be killed. You see, it is against our laws to mingle with humans in such a way as to expose ourselves in this manner. It was then that we started our training, far sooner that most protectors begin to train. His training first began for his own safety, but his talents far surpassed my wildest expectations. When I first heard of the incident with his parents, I had hoped that I had trained him well enough for his own survival. When he was discovered three days later adrift in the ocean, I cannot tell you how overjoyed I was. For he did not only survive the explosion that killed his parents, but also had been strong enough to ward off whatever forces Theron had sent after him. The pool was deep enough to cover half my body, and at first glance it seemed like an oasis of calm in the ice-cold mountain terrain.
But then something strange happened: the pool started to move. It was as though someone was pushing it from behind; the surface ripples grew stronger and larger until they formed into waves that sloshed over each other with increasing speed.
I’d been watching these pools for about 10 years now and they’re always unpredictable. This time was no different; as soon as one began to rise up it would begin falling back again almost immediately afterwards – only now instead of just being pushed around by its own weight or whatever else happens naturally within those icy depths beneath us … well… something more sinister seems responsible too…

We opened it to find three men standing in front of us: the three riders we saw earlier that morning.

"Sir, we are here to deliver a letter," said one of them.

I took him by surprise and snatched the envelope from him before he finished speaking.

"Where is he going?" demanded Mr. Jones as I handed him back the envelope.

"He's leaving for the town called Port Royal."

"He told us so himself. We were just following instructions from Captain Morgan."

"Instructions?" asked Mr. Jones skeptically.

"We were told not only to bring this message to you personally – but also to make sure nobody else knew where he went!"

My friend is an avid fisherman. She loves going out with her son, a boy who has always loved fishing and who can now take care of the little minnow bait that we use for catching bigger game fish. She was on vacation last year in a small coastal town, not too far from where we are right now. She had been fishing for hours and hours with no luck whatsoever when suddenly she had seen one of those little fish swimming around in one place. So she got up from her chair by the water's edge, put down her poles and bent over to scoop them into her bucket.
I asked how many she had caught, figuring that it wouldn't be many since the shrimp and minnows are so tiny they can't hold much air in their bodies for very long before they die.
I didn't have time to say anything else because my friend began counting them out loud. The numbers came faster than I could keep pace with them but I heard her say "one hundred, two hundred," then "three hundred," then "four hundred" before finally saying "five thousand."
Five-thousand! There were five thousand little shrimp sitting in that plastic container!

Elenore Forbes, known by her stage name Elena Fisher (née Forbes; born 1959), is the founder of the Elena Fisher Foundation, which supports cancer research.

Early life

Elena was born in London on 18 November.[2] She attended the St. Martin-in-the-Fields Church School and the St Mary Abbots School, in Kensington, where she was a student from 4th grade.[3]

Elena was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma at age 7 in May and underwent radiation therapy and chemotherapy at the Royal Marsden Hospital. After a year in remission she was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in January, and again underwent treatment at the Royal Marsden Hospital.[4]

She attended University College London, studying psychology with a specialization as a clinical psychologist.[5] In 2003 Elena was awarded an MA degree for her dissertation entitled "Cognitive Processing of the Illness Experience: A Clinical Study".

prefix_text: The literature highlighted three main approaches in use when a person with dementia says something that is false. The first, known as _reality orientation_, seeks to provide
reference_text: provide supports such as orientation boards and sign-posting to help the person with dementia understand where s/he is. The second approach is known as _validation therapy_. This approach seeks to promote empathy between the person with dementia and his/her carer. Validation therapy encourages the carer to tap into the emotion of the person with dementia and empathise with her/him. The third approach is called _therapeutic lying_ (fibbing or telling a white lie). There is no clear consensus regarding the use of this approach as it raises questions about honesty, trust and integrity. The level of dementia is recognised as having great relevance on deciding whether therapeutic lying is appropriate or not. The acceptability of therapeutic lying is recognised to be a complex issue and its use depends on a number of factors, including who is lying, the relationships involved, the motive behind the lie, the nature of the lie and the understanding and capacity of the person with dementia and their stage in the disease process. Of particular significance is the apparent high prevalence of therapeutic lying despite the fact that a review of the codes of professional conducts state that the practitioner must tell the truth. In fact being untruthful is likely to put professional registration at risk. This apparent lack of coherence between practice and regulation needs to be addressed and merits further investigation.

The second approach is called _reality acceptance_. Staff using reality acceptance do not challenge or contradict what the person believes. It involves accepting and responding to what they say or ask, even if the information is wrong; they may then try redirecting attention by changing topic, activity or environment.
Finally comes a third approach known as _reality orientation and acceptance_. It is a more balanced approach that uses both reality orientations strategies (providing accurate information) as well as reality accepting strategies (responding to what the patient has said) in combination.
All of these approaches were used at least some times during an interview with staff and patients in this review but it wasn't clear how often each one of them were used.
This study shows that there may be better ways to manage patients' beliefs in order improve their quality-of-life than just correcting their beliefs. In particular using approaches that accept their perspective may help them feel understood while maintaining their self-esteem.

prefix_text: The carers talked about a range of different strategies that they used to manage the person's anxiety, stress or agitation. These ranged from: telling the truth,
reference_text: moving on the conversation, reframing the situation, distraction and "going with" the person. Carers said that at times, in the interest of the person with dementia, they confronted or corrected statements. The carers' approach to lying is best described as "empathetic deception", in other words, it was done in the person's best interest, in a context of knowing what matters to the person and in a way that maintained the person's dignity. Carers were influenced by the capacity of the person with dementia and were more likely to tell the truth in the earlier stages and lie by omission or avoidance in the later stages of the disease. At the heart of carers' actions was the intention to benefit the person with dementia. They identified an individualised approach, tailored to the person's needs and life history as being critical[1]. Such an approach they felt was not compatible within a system of hard and fast rules on "what to do". In the context of the actions that formal carers should take, carers saw that therapeutic lying was appropriate when it benefited and respected the person's dignity. They viewed themselves as the representatives of the person with dementia in the later stages because they knew them, knew their life history and knew what mattered to them. Consequently carers considered they had a role to play in preserving the rights of the person with dementia and they recommended the use of care plans, reflecting this knowledge, in formal care settings.

People with dementia may repeat themselves. They may ask you the same question many times or say something that you know is not true. It can be challenging to know how to respond, but a new research project by the University of Hertfordshire is trying to help people understand what might work best.
Researchers from Psychology in Ageing and Dementia (PAD) at UH have developed a tool to help carers understand which strategies might work best for them in different situations. The new resource has just been launched and will also be available for download on the PAD website. Dr Helen Williams, who led this work, said: “It was important to find out which approaches worked well for different carers so we could develop our tool in a way that would support them. We hope this helps people understand which approach would work best when supporting someone.”
The research involved 168 participants from across Hertfordshire taking part in 654 surveys on how they responded if somebody asked them a question they knew was wrong or said something untrue.
People were asked a variety of questions such as what day it was, where they lived or what had happened earlier on that day.

prefix_text: This study confirms that lying to the person with dementia with an intention to cause harm is never an acceptable strategy. The use of therapeutic lying was however considered to be
reference_text: an acceptable strategy by health professionals, informal/unpaid carers and people with dementia (PWD). The acceptability of therapeutic lying as an approach carries the caveat that it is being used to promote wellbeing and safeguard wellbeing of the person with dementia. The intention must be to minimise harm and distress for the person with dementia. The appropriateness of this approach can however only be determined on a case by case individual basis. The acceptance of therapeutic lying as a strategy is in keeping with other research (Culley et al. 2013; Tuckett 2012; James et al. 2006). The acceptance of therapeutic lying does however raise significant questions in relation to the codes of conduct, ethical and best practice guidelines governing the practice of healthcare professionals; all of which specify the need for truth telling and stipulate that lying to patients is inappropriate.

Validation therapy means that the patient's feelings, emotions and expressions are accepted in their current situation and the person is not told that they are wrong.
"Validation therapy is an important concept in dementia care, even though we don't have evidence from large randomised studies. In our view, validation should be applied as much or even more than the pharmacological treatment of neuropsychiatric symptoms", explains the leader of this research, Professor Lars Hallberg.
"Many people think you just treat a person with Alzheimer's disease with medication or by providing good physical care. The truth about Alzheimer's is far more complex: it means not only that a person is forgetful but also that it can affect his whole being, including his sense perceptions and how he experiences himself in relation to himself and others", says Lars Hallberg.
"Many health professionals are still not aware enough about how important validation can be when treating patients suffering from dementia".

prefix_text: In conclusion there were no major conflicts or differences of opinion among people with dementia, informal/unpaid carers and health professionals in terms of when it is acceptable
reference_text: to lie to a person with dementia. The consensus is that when caring for a person with dementia in the context of the best approach to take when they ask questions or make statements that are false, that there is no single approach that will suit each person or be appropriate every time. Rather than prescriptive guidelines, carers should undertake an individualised assessment that enables a judgement to be made as to the best approach to take in any given context. A key requirement for making these judgements is that carers must know the person with dementia including their preferences and know what their families think. In the context of nursing home care the detailed life history of the person with dementia is considered crucial to this process. Consequently the governance structure within which practitioners are working must take cognisance of this and focus on capacity development for carers through training and education as opposed to creating a prescriptive model of care. It is also clear that a discrepancy exists between respective health professional codes of conduct and ethical guidelines and health professionals' use of therapeutic lying, which is an alternative approach to truth telling or correcting the person with dementia. This has serious practical implications for health professionals. This paradox also increases the risk for violation of the dignity of people with dementia and of professional carers and therefore the formal regulatory frameworks merit urgent review and attention.

prefix_text: The promotion of dignity and the protection of rights for people with dementia was a key driver for the research team. Dignity is a notoriously difficult concept to define and
reference_text: this study is guided by Jacobson's (2012) dignity encounters model. Jacobson (2012) separates dignity into human dignity that which we all have by nature of being human and social dignity, which is the result of our encounters with each other. Every social encounter is depicted as having one of two potential outcomes  promotion of dignity or a violation of dignity. The promotion of dignity is, she argues, dependent on trust and respectful communication. When two people meet if the more powerful person (carer) does not take account of the particular needs of the more vulnerable person (with dementia) there is a risk for violation of dignity.

prefix_text: Developed in the United States in the late 1960s, reality orientation (RO) was initially used to improve the quality of life of confused older persons. Its
reference_text: use was extended to persons with dementia in the early 1980s. RO, described as a cognitive-oriented intervention (American Psychiatric Association, 1997), aims to improve cognition. Sessions may be delivered one to one but are typically delivered at a group level, usually in a classroom setting and involve all staff caring for the person with dementia. Staff caring for the person with dementia and trained in the process of RO facilitate orientation to reality with the aid of a variety of props including orientation boards which detail the present date, time and location, discussion of recent events and sign-posting (Spector et al. 2000; Spector et al. 2010).

use spread rapidly throughout North America and Europe and by 1975 was being used widely for older adults with cognitive impairment.
In recent years, there has been a resurgence of interest in RO as a treatment for dementia-related behavioural disturbances and agitation. RO therapy is based on two fundamental principles:
- Orientation to reality is a process whereby individuals are encouraged through verbal interaction to recognize and become aware that something or someone does not fit within the normal framework for that situation.
For example: "I see there is an animal on your bed. You don't usually have any animals in your room. Let's go check it out."
- When individuals recognize that they are wrong, they are encouraged to accept their mistakes, correct them immediately, and continue to be attentive so as not to make another one later.
RO has been shown repeatedly over several decades of clinical research studies to improve orientation in persons with dementia. The therapy also has been found useful for improving agitation related problems.
Although there were early criticisms about its effectiveness because it was thought it might cause distress or agitation among persons who did not have an orientation deficit or who had mild impairment only,
it now appears that this type of therapy can be helpful regardless
of severity. There does appear however,
to be some risk when using it with

prefix_text: Early observational studies (Salter, 1975; Cornbleth & Cornbleth, 1978) reported that group RO was associated with improvement in cognitive functioning and general
reference_text: behaviour. Likewise a Cochrane systematic review of RO for dementia in 2000 reported positive outcomes (Spector et al. 2000). Six randomised controlled trials (RCTs), with a total of 125 participants with a diagnosis of dementia based on DSM-IV or ICD-10 criteria were included in the review meta-analysis. A statistically non-significant change in cognition and behaviour was found but the trend was in favour of RO. The review concluded that there was some evidence that RO improved cognitive functioning and behaviour in older people with dementia but these positive effects may be short lived. Over time however RO became associated with a more inflexible challenging approach toward people with dementia and its use declined (Woods et al. 2012) It is now subsumed under the umbrella of cognitive stimulation therapy which seeks to employ the positive elements of RO in a more sensitive and person centred approach (Woods et al. 2012).

prefix_text: Validation therapy was conceived as a possible remedy to the seeming lack of efficacy of RO in nursing home residents with advanced dementia. Feil (1993) describes validation
reference_text: therapy as a therapy that facilitates communication between carers and people with dementia. Validation therapy is based on the acceptance of reality and the personal truth of a person's experience and it puts emphasis on the emotional content of what the person with dementia is expressing (Feil, 1992). According to the Nuffield Council on bioethics, (2009) it may be appropriate to seek to respond to the emotions involved even if this involves some degree of latitude with the truth. prefix_text: Its creator, Naomi Feil (1993) outlines that validation therapy, contrary to RO, does not seek to orient the person with dementia to the present but encourages
reference_text: the carer to empathise with the person with dementia. Strategies include both the person with dementia and their carer retreating together into the past, and in doing so, experiencing the lived and more vivid experiences of the person with dementia. Feil (1993) contends that living in the past is not as demanding of the person with dementia as it concentrates on their preserved abilities, i.e., their ability to recall past memories. In contrast to living in an unfamiliar present, retreating to a familiar past is far more pleasing and less stressful for the person with dementia (Douglas et al. 2004). According to Kitwood (1997), validation therapy is recognised as offering a good level of empathy with the intention of understanding a person's entire frame of reference. However, researchers argue that, like many psychosocial interventions advocated for use in dementia care, validation therapy does not have a definitive theoretical underpinning and the evidence to support its use stems largely from observational studies. These studies report that, validation therapy promotes better communication and interaction between the carer and person with dementia; it has a positive effect on behavioural symptoms and enhances the quality of life of both carer and person with dementia (Bleathman & Morton, 1988; Babins, 1998). However, converse to findings arising from qualitative studies, evidence from the most recent Cochrane systematic review (Neal & Wright, 2003), evaluating the effectiveness of validation therapy for people with dementia concludes that there is inadequate evidence to support the use of validation therapy for people with dementia. Three RCTs met the inclusion criteria for this review but because of the diversity in duration of treatment, lack of comparability between control groups and outcome measurements, pooled analysis was not feasible. The review authors concluded that, as yet, there is insufficient evidence to support the use of validation therapy for people with dementia.

prefix_text: Lying is a deliberate form of deception and is described as having three key elements: it communicates information, the person communicating the information intends to deceive or mislead and
reference_text: the person receiving the information perceives the information to be true (Ludwig, 1965). In contrast a 'white lie' or a 'fib' is defined as a "a lie that is told in order to be polite or to stop someone from being upset by the truth" (Online Cambridge Dictionary, 2015). A white lie therefore is one not intended to harm the receiver. In reality it is often intended to benefit the receiver or make them feel good. However white lies are not without harm. They do actually deprive the receiver of information they might find beneficial, even if they do not like it and the person delivering the white lie may find lying an easier option in the future (Green 2015).

prefix_text: There are many ethical concerns associated with the practice of therapeutic lying which make it very challenging (Culley et al. 2013). The main ethical principles affected are
reference_text: autonomy, beneficence and non-maleficence. Autonomy centres on the person's right to self-determination and the carer's role in promoting independence for the purpose of realising self-determination (Barber & Lyness, 2001). Beneficence is about making decisions that are in the best interest of the person with dementia and non-maleficence is about minimising harm to the person with dementia (Barber & Lyness, 2001). Therapeutic lying can threaten a person's autonomy when it is used to deny the voice of the person with dementia in their care whilst only achieving short term goals such as reducing agitation (Brannelly and Whitewood (2014). However, therapeutic lying may be considered acceptable when non-maleficence and compassion are its motives (Sperber 2014; Stubbs, 2013; Tuckett, 2012). It is also important to consider the impact of therapeutic lying on the carer. Trust is a moral principle of care, and lying compromises the trusting relationship between the person with dementia and their carer (Feil & Altman, 2004; Schermer, 2007; Barnes & Brannelly, 2008). This behaviour/action may therefore have a negative impact on the carer who may feel uncomfortable with the deception and the associated impact on their integrity (Schermer, 2007). The literature also highlights that the stage of dementia is an important consideration when deciding to use therapeutic lying. Taylor (2007), writing from the perspective of the person with dementia, asserts that lying is not acceptable to people in the early stages of dementia as it heightens that disconnect that they experience from reality. However as dementia progresses and capacity diminishes, the less possible it becomes for the person with dementia to entertain beliefs, either false or true. Schermer (2007) purports that lying to someone requires a capacity to hold beliefs about what is true and what is not, thus making it conceptually impossible to lie to someone in an advanced state of dementia. If a person is not aware of being 'lied' to due to memory loss, the 'deception' may be viewed as less threatening and potentially beneficial (Kartalova-O'Doherty et al. 2014). Lying with an intention to cause harm is never acceptable.

prefix_text: The literature review found mixed perceptions on the use of therapeutic lying when caring for people with dementia. For some any type of lying is seen as deceptive, a form
reference_text: of abuse and using lies for the purpose of compliance is considered a form of treachery (Kitwood, 1997; Bush, 2003). James et al. (2006) explored the use of therapeutic lying using an exploratory survey of staff (n =112) working in residential homes, elderly mentally ill units and hospital wards from the United Kingdom (UK) and ROI. They found that the majority of health professionals (96.5%) reported that they lied to residents with dementia. Over half the staff (51.1%) used lying to promote compliance and to benefit staff and save time (30.2%). Likewise, Culley et al. (2013) found that of the 29 psychiatrists surveyed on the use of therapeutic lying, the majority (69%) reported they had lied to people with dementia when it was deemed to be in the best interests of the person. Elvish et al. (2010) also found that lying was more acceptable to health care professionals when the focus was to reduce harm to the person with dementia. Their study used a two phased design, the first of which involved developing and piloting the attitudes towards lying to people with dementia (ALPD) questionnaire; and the second aimed at validating the questionnaire at a workshop. In phase one, participants (n=151), including psychologists, nurses, care workers and social workers, were asked to complete the newly developed questionnaire. Results showed that lying was considered more acceptable when it was in the person's best interest or to prevent injury as opposed to being used for the purpose of compliance. Tuckett (2012) also found lying was used by nurses and allied health professionals (n=18) caring for people with dementia for the purpose of eliminating harm and to control behaviour. In this study, the consequences of lying were important as identified by the concept of 'settling' a resident by lying to them. Participants identified validating the person with dementia's reality as benevolent lying as opposed to 'out and out' lying. It is interesting to note that despite the fact that professional guidelines and codes of conduct do not support lying to patients irrespective of cognitive status health professionals report that lying to people with dementia is an approach they use (Culley et al. 2013; Tuckett 2012, Nuffield Council on Bioethics, 2009; James et al. 2006)

prefix_text: Few studies have explored people with dementia's perceptions of lying. Day et al. (2011) using a grounded theory approach explored lying from the perspective of the person
reference_text: with dementia. In this study, persons with dementia (n=14) felt that lying was acceptable if it was in the best interest of the person, but not if it caused distress or devalued the person. Green (2015) in her unpublished Masters thesis interviewed carers to explore the impact of therapeutic lying or therapeutic fibbing. All participants had experience of caring for the person with dementia from diagnosis to the advanced stage. The findings found that carers overwhelmingly supported the use of therapeutic lying. For them the benefits of reducing or preventing emotionally upsetting or agitated situations for the person with dementia outweighed any ethical or moral concerns. Most carers also focused on the value of therapeutic lying in improving and benefiting the person with dementia rather than the impact on themselves. However the relationship between the carer and the person with dementia, the importance of really understanding and knowing the person with dementia was identified as key to using therapeutic lying.

prefix_text: In summary, the acceptability of therapeutic lying is a complex issue and its use depends on a number of factors, including who is lying, the relationships involved,
reference_text: the motive behind the lie, the nature of the lie and the understanding and capacity of the person being lied to including their stage in the disease process. Ultimately, it seems that the appropriateness of therapeutic lying can only be determined on an individual basis (Sprinks (2013). prefix_text: Jacobson (2009) identifies two types of dignity, 'human dignity' which is similar to universal dignity and'social dignity' which is created in the interpersonal
reference_text: interactions between individuals, groups and societies. Jacobson's work is grounded in human rights and promotion of equality. Jacobson argues that every human interaction has the potential to be a 'dignity encounter'. These encounters she argues can result in one of two outcomes: the promotion of dignity or the violation of dignity. Dignity violation is more likely to result from an encounter in which there is a power imbalance with one person placed in a position of vulnerability due for example to cognitive impairment as in the case of the person with dementia. The impact is further exacerbated when the other actor is not sympathetic due to prejudice, personality or ignorance. The setting in which encounters take place can also exacerbate the situation. So-called harsh environments that fail to take account of the diversity of users, serve to reinforce distance and power imbalances. Jacobson (2009) characterises these settings as hierarchal and inflexible characterised by stress and a sense of urgency but deficient in resources. The people working in such environments are less likely to be empathetic to others and are also more likely to perceive questioning or non-cooperation as an 'attack on their dignity'. Being in a 'position' of vulnerability is at the core of dignity violation. This vulnerability may stem from internal factors such as physical disability, and/or cognitive impairment and external factors such as lack of knowledge or skills.

prefix_text: This literature review firstly examined the published literature on the use of RO, validation therapy, aikido and therapeutic lying for use with people with dementia. The
reference_text: dearth of published research studies on any of these approaches, in particular the absence of randomised controlled trials, makes it difficult to ascertain the effectiveness and to advocate for any particular approach. Furthermore the context and setting in which interpersonal interactions occur govern the extent to which dignity is promoted or violated. The second phase of this review involved an examination of national and international guidelines on dementia care and care of older people and national and international codes of conduct, ethics and best practice guidelines for healthcare professionals. This revealed that there is little formal direction available to health professionals in how best to respond to persons with dementia who ask questions or make statements that are false apart from codes of practice which outlaw lying in any form and failure to comply with same has serious consequences. Yet once a number of caveats are in place carers and people with dementia appear to accept the merits of therapeutic lying. However, it is clear that further research is required that include the perceptions of people with dementia formal and informal carers as well as the views of other established experts in the field of dementia and care of older people. This will help inform the development of guidelines on the best approach to use when persons with dementia ask questions or make statements that are false.

A qualitative descriptive approach is appropriate when seeking to understand complex 'phenomena' (as is the case in this study) and the use of this approach provides a description of and facilitates understanding of persons' with dementia and informal/unpaid carer's experiences and perceptions. The strength of qualitative descriptive designs in comparison to other qualitative approaches is that it "obtains straight and largely unadorned (i.e. minimally theorized) answers to questions of relevance to practitioners and policy makers" (Sandelowski 2000 p.337). Using this approach enabled the collection of detailed feedback from persons with dementia and informal/unpaid carers on their experiences. Qualitative descriptive design uses an "eclectic but reasonable and well-considered combination" of sampling, data collection and data analysis techniques (Sandelowski 2000). In this study focus group interviewing was used to collect data from participants.

prefix_text: Focus groups are particularly useful when the aim is to learn about service user's perceptions, feelings or thinking on an issue (Kreuger 1994; Beya
reference_text: & Nicoll 2000; Owens 2001; Halcomb et al. 2007). The aim is not to achieve consensus but rather to investigate experiences, needs and understanding (Crabtree and Miller 1992). A focus group normally comprises between 8  12 people (Stewart and Shamdasni 1992; Kreuger 1994) and the more homogenous the group the more likely it will result in candid discussions (Morgan 1992; Kruger 1994). An interview guide developed from the expertise of the researchers and an analysis of the literature was used to guide each set of interviews i.e. with people with dementia/memory problems and carers. In addition the CORTE interviewing framework (Murphy et al. 2014a) was used to guide the interview process with people with dementia. This guide consists of four main areas; gaining COnsent, maximising Responses, Telling the story, and Ending on a high (CORTE guide). This process maximises the meaningful involvement of persons with dementia, ensuring that their voices are heard and to the fore. Two members of the research team attended each focus group. One acted as facilitator (moderator). This person asked the questions on the interview guide, clarified issues with the group and explored the extent to which views expressed by a group member were shared by the entire group. The other (assistant moderator) listened to focus group participant perspectives, gathered demographic details from participants, took notes on group dynamics and ensured that the recording equipment was working. Each focus group took approximately 60 minutes including the opportunities taken for time breaks. The focus groups were convened at a time and place that was mutually convenient to participants and the researchers. Informed consent was gained from each of the participants prior to commencing the focus groups, see ethics section below for further details.

In-vivo codes (derived from participants' words) were initially used to label these descriptions. Once all data has been coded, each code was examined and overlapping codes were collapsed, to form larger more inclusive categories. This process helped to make explicit the links between categories, enabling a hierarchical structure to emerge showing categories and their subcategories. The final categories were then organised into "meaningful clusters" (Hsieh and Shannon 2005 p.1279) that "best fits the data" (Sandelowski 2000 p.339), for example, most prevalent to least prevalent themes. The computer software package NVivo 10 was used to assist the storage and management of the qualitative data and make the analysis process more transparent to scrutiny.
